column2: 2016    RE:   Water Main Replacement Project #1201083    Dear Neighbor
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s Building a New Chicago infrastructure investment  program
column5: I would like to provide you with information about an  upcoming water main construction project in your neighborhood.      In mid-June
column6: Department of Water Management crews will begin the work to install 2
column7: 545 feet of  new 8-inch water main in S. Justine Street (W. 65th Street-W. 67th Street) and in W. 65th Street (S.  Ashland Avenue-S. Loomis Boulevard). The old water main dates back to 1890
column8: and needs to be  replaced.     If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column9: please go to  BuildingANewChicago.org to register for the WaterALERT program.  Simply enter your name
column10: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.    By signing up for the WaterALERT emails
column11: you will be notified as the project enters each new  construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column12: to the installation of new  pipes
column13: to the final restoration of the street.    When we are working in the street
column14: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column15: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column16: a travel lane will be left  open for local traffic only.     We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column17: but cars will need to be moved by the start of the  next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.    We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do everything  possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column18: and conducting ourselves as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.     Should you have any questions or concerns
column19: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column20: or call any of the following numbers:       24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311    16th  Ward Office: 773-863-0220    DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635      Genwmnot03032016   When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
column21: we will interrupt water  service.  We give you 24-hour notice when this is to happen.  However
column22: in the event of an emergency  shutdown during construction
column23: we may not be able to give you prior warning.    Flushing after Your Service Line has been Connected to the New Water Main     Now that your old water main has been replaced and your water service has been connected to the  new water main
column24: it is important to flush your plumbing of any sediment
column26: including  any lead to maintain water quality.      Sediment
column28: including any lead may collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of  your faucets.  These screens should be removed prior to flushing.       (1) Please find the closest available tap (an outside  hose spigot
column29: laundry sink faucet or bathtub) to where  the water comes into the home that is not used for  drinking water. Fully open the cold water tap and let  the water run for at least 5 minutes.  Next flush any  other cold water faucets on that floor for at least 5  minutes.   (2)Move to the next highest floor and repeat.  (3) Move to additional floors in sequence and flush          any taps or faucets for at least 5 minutes.             If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column30: or if you would like your water  tested
column31: please call us at 311.  For additional advice and information visit  http://www.epa.gov/il/advice-chicago-residents-about-lead-drinking-water.    Routine Flushing  If your water line has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours
column32: it is advised that you flush for at  least 5 minutes to maintain water quality.  This may include flushing the toilet
column33: taking a shower and  doing laundry.      MeterSave  Lastly
column34: if you don’t already have one
column35: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter in your  home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free program
column36: go to  www.metersave.org.    Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important infrastructure  improvement project.          Sincerely

column1: 25804`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/dhr/supp_info/JobSpecifications/JobSpecName/COORD-OF-PUBLIC-UTILITIES_5981.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`    CLASS TITLE:  Coordinator of Public Utilities     CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CLASS:  Under general supervision
column2: coordinates construction  schedules with public utilities and other agencies; and performs related duties as required.     ESSENTIAL DUTIES:  Notifies utility representatives and other public and private agencies of  scheduled construction projects to coordinate dates
column3: locations and sequence of activity; reviews  the construction plans of other agencies to establish construction schedules and resolve  conflicts; represents the department at utility and preconstruction meetings to plan construction  schedules; acts as liaison between department engineers
column4: construction managers and utilities to  resolve scheduling problems that arise during construction; works with the Board of  Underground to resolve conflicts; obtains data on utility property locations at project sites and  forwards information to project design and construction engineers; maintains records of project  schedules and prepares status reports.    RELATED DUTIES:  Coordinates public utility involvement in special events for the department.     MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS:    Training and Experience.  Five years of progressively responsible experience in the construction  and inspection of public works projects
column5: or an equivalent combination of training and experience  is required.  A valid State of Illinois driver’s license is required.    Knowledge
column6: Abilities and Skill.  Good knowledge of construction management.  Good  knowledge of project scheduling.  Good knowledge of public utilities.     Ability to work with public and private officials
column7: engineers and contractors.  Ability to coordinate  scheduling with a variety of agencies.  Ability to inspect construction projects.     Skill in the application of the principles of construction project scheduling.  Good skill in reading  blue prints and construction plans.  Good oral and written communication skills.  Good human  relation skills.                        Code:  5981  Operation and Construction Service  Engineering
column8: Designing and Structural Group  General Engineering Series   Code:  5981  Operation and Construction Service  Engineering
column9: Designing and Structural Group  General Engineering Series       CLASS TITLE:  Coordinator of Public Utilities     (Cont’d)    Working Conditions.  General office environment.  Unavoidable exposure to inclement weather.    Equipment.  Standard office equipment.             NOTE: While the list of essential duties is intended to be as inclusive as possible

column1: 11854`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/bacp/rulesandregs/consumerfactsheets/bpaordinancefactsheet.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`                                                                               What Businesses Should Know About the   BPA-Free Kids Ordinace   Chicago Municipal Code
column2: Chapter 7-28-637      BPA-Free Kids Ordinance                      On  May  13
column4: the  Chicago  City  Council  enacted  the  BPA-Free  Kids  Ordinance. The ordinance restricts the sale of any container designed to be  filled with food or liquid to be used for a child under the age of three that  contains Bisphenol A. The ordinance goes into effect on January 31
column5: 2010.    What is Bisphenol A?  Bisphenol A
column7: is a chemical that is produced in  large quantites used primarily in the production of certain types of plastics.    What is Restricted?   Selling bottles
column10: or any other container designed to be filled with  food or liquid
column11: intended for a child under the age of three
column13: in  the City of Chicago. In addition
column14: selling these items will require a label indicating  that the item is free of BPA.       When does the ordinance go into effect?   The ordinance goes into effect on January 31
column15: 2010.    What are the fines for violating this ordinance?   Businesses found selling products containing BPA face Administative Hearing  citations
column16: violations and or fines.   1st offense  2nd offense       $100-$300      $300-$500         For more information    visit www.cityofchicago.org/bacp                                       or call 312-74-GOBIZ (312-744-6249)  Richard M. Daley   Mayor    For complaints call 311              Department of Business Affairs and Consumer Protection  Norma I. Reyes

Comments on both the Rules and Regulations for Taxicab Medallion  License Holders and MCC Chapter 9-112 must be submitted via e-mail to  BACPPV@cityofchicago.org before 6pm on Friday

column1: 19021`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2016construction/mar_2016/20160303_Springfield_30w.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`                   Sewer Main Replacement Project #7016   March 3
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s “Building a New Chicago” infrastructure  improvement program
column5: I would like to provide you  with information about an upcoming sewer main construction project in your  neighborhood.     In early March
column6: the Department of Water Management’s private contractor will begin  preliminary construction work around Belmont and Springfield. In mid-April
column7: Department  of Water Management crews will begin to install 2
column10: and 24-inch  new sewer main in N. Springfield Avenue (Belmont-Barry)
column12: in N. Davlin Court (Barry-200 feet west of Milwaukee)
column14: and in N. Harding Avenue (Barry-180 feet south of Belmont). The  old sewer dates back to 1911 and needs to be replaced.     For the duration of our contractor’s work (early March-mid-April)
column15: eastbound traffic on  Belmont will be closed. Traffic will be detoured from Kedzie north to Addison
column18: when we are working in the street
column19: we may close  it to traffic for safety reasons
column20: but you will always be able to reach your home or business.   Outside of working hours
column21: a travel lane will be left open for local traffic only.     We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am- 4pm).  We are agreeable to parking outside of those hours
column22: but cars will need to be moved  by the start of the next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking as possible.    We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do  everything possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column23: and  conducting ourselves as good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on  your street.     Should you have any questions or concerns
column24: you can either ask the construction foreman  during the project
column25: or call any of the following numbers:       24-Hour Service and Information Line:  311    30th Ward Office: 773-794-3095     DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635   Lastly
column26: if you don’t already have one
column27: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter  in your home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free  program
column28: go to www.metersave.org.    Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important  infrastructure improvement project.          Sincerely
